   Assessment and Plan
 ALTERED MENTAL STATUS (NOT DELIRIUM)
 AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
 CIRRHOSIS OF LIVER, ALCOHOLIC
 FEVER, UNKNOWN ORIGIN (FUO, HYPERTHERMIA, PYREXIA)
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 2**])
 SUBDURAL HEMORRHAGE (SDH)
   46M with ESLD c/b ascites, varices and encephalopathy; course
   complicated by intraparenchymal bleed, pneumonia, encephalopathy and
   current hypoxemia.
   .
   # Hypoxemia, fevers: Likely pneumonia.  Patient growing enterobacter
   cloacae which is pan-sensitive.  Continues to spike, however, despite
   broad coverage with antibiotics.  ABG demonstrates respiratory acidosis
   with metabolic alkalosis.  Acute incident today was in the context of
   worsening secretions; could have had mucous plugging.  In addition
   enterobacter has inducible resistance, perhaps the patient is no longer
   responding to the therapy. s/p extubation on [**11-21**].
   - ID consult, follow up recs
   - d/c Vanc and Flagyl
   - Continue Meropenem x14 day course, D1 = [**11-21**], d/c after [**12-6**]
   - Lasix prn as pt
s respiratory status and hypoxia improved with
   aggressive diuresis
   - Additional Lasix 80mg IV now
   - Intubate electively given acute desat this morning, likely mucus plug
   which is unable to be suctioned up
   .
   # Hypernatremia:  Monitoring Na closely.
   - Increased free water flushes to 250mL Q4h
   - check pm lytes
   .
   # Coagulopathy: [**1-12**] hepatic dysfunction, mild DIC on admission. Now
   holding off on repleting coagulation factors and blood products given
   stable over several days.  Minimal bleeding with suctioning.  On [**11-23**]
   patient had 2 units PRBC transfused without appropriate increase in
   hct, but no clear source of bleeding. CT head, torso yesterday ([**11-24**])
   showed no source of bleeding.
   - daily coags, HCT
   - transfuse as necessary
   .
   #. Head Bleed s/p Fall: Occurred on [**2156-11-11**] and in setting of liver
   disease-related coagulopathy. Repeat scans show no significant changes
   ([**11-13**] and [**11-16**]) and neuro exam stable as above.
   - cont dilantin for seizure ppx, follow levels; per neurosurgery, pt
   will need to continue on dilantin until his h/s f/u in 1 mo w. head CT
   - daily neurology exams, follow INR and CBC daily
   - fall precautions, low bed
   - f/u plastics recs
   .
   #. Altered mental status: Likely secondary to hypoxia Improving. Was
   secondary to intraparenchymal hemorrhage, and hepatic encephalopathy.
   The patient has known decompensated liver disease with a previous
   history of encephalopathy.
   - cont lactulose and rifaximin ([**2-12**] BM per day)
   .
   #. Anemia: Likely due to head wound bleeding.
   - Daily HCTs, coags as above
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Will monitor NGT output for bleeding
   .
   #. ESLD: No viral etiologies per OSH records. Most likely related to
   EtOH. Patient had EtOH level on admission. Pt also has long standing
   ductal dilitation. MELD is currently 26. In records that has varices
   though unclear what or if esophageal.
   - cont lactulose and rifaximin
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - trend MELD scores
   .
   #. Transverse Process Fractures: Per neurosurgery are non-operative.
   Does not need cervical collar or log roll precautions.
   - Follow-up with Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 363**] in 4 weeks with a non-contrast head  CT.
   Call [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8464**] to schedule an appointment on the [**Location (un) 9850**] of the
   [**Hospital Unit Name 9838**] - [**Hospital Unit Name 9839**].
   .
   #. Shallow Toe Ulcer: Podiatry saw and signed off. Likely mild
   cellulitis treated with broad spec abx. Needs out pt f/u
   - make outpt f/u apt
   .
   # FEN: Follow nutrition recommendations. Start tubefeeds, 250cc free
   water flushes q4h. Replete lytes prn.
   # PPX: PPI IV BID for now assuming there are varices/gastritis, no
   heparin, bowel regimen, venodynes
   # CODE: Full code.
   # Access: PICC line c/s placed.
   .
   # CONTACT: [**Name (NI) 83**] formal HCP. Brother has been signing consents. [**Name (NI) 2255**]
   (brother) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9357**]. Other family numbers: [**Name (NI) 1515**] (mother) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9642**], and [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9359**]. Girlfriend [**Name (NI) 7080**] [**Name (NI) 9340**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9341**] has been
   main decision maker. GF was on the way to getting HCP status when
   recent fall happened.  GF updated on [**11-24**]. Plan for family meeting
   with social work and hepatology today at 215pm to discuss prognosis and
   goals of care.
   # Dispo:  ICU pending improvement of respiratory status.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   PICC Line - [**2156-11-27**] 06:40 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 46-year-old male with ESLD, cirrhosis of the liver, and a history of encephalopathy. He is currently in the ICU due to respiratory failure, acute and chronic liver disease, and sepsis.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38.1°C (100.6°F)
* Heart rate: 95 bpm (normal range: 90-97 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 128/55 mmHg (normal range: 74-133/50-66 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 18 breaths per minute (normal range: 15-22 breaths per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 96% (normal range: 95-100%)

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 6.8 K/uL (normal range: 4.5-11.0 K/uL)
* Hemoglobin: 7.9 g/dL (normal range: 13.5-17.5 g/dL)
* Platelet count: 43 K/uL (normal range: 150-450 K/uL)
* Creatinine: 0.6 mg/dL (normal range: 0.5-1.1 mg/dL)
* Blood urea nitrogen: 38 mg/dL (normal range: 7-20 mg/dL)
* Sodium: 144 mg/dL (normal range: 135-145 mg/dL)
* Potassium: 4.6 mEq/L (normal range: 3.5-5.5 mEq/L)
* Chloride: 104 mEq/L (normal range: 98-112 mEq/L)
* Bicarbonate: 31 mEq/L (normal range: 22-32 mEq/L)

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Altered mental status (not delirium)
* Airway, inability to protect (risk for aspiration, altered gag, airway clearance, cough)
* Cirrhosis of the liver, alcoholic
* Fever, unknown origin (FUO, hyperthermia, pyrexia)
* Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS)
* Subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

The patient's medications include:

* Meropenem (antibiotic)
* Lasix (diuretic)
* Pantoprazole (Protonix) (proton pump inhibitor)
* Furosemide (Lasix) (diuretic)
* Dilantin (anticonvulsant)
* Lactulose and rifaximin (liver disease treatment)

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure
* Sepsis
* Liver failure
* Coagulopathy
* Head bleed
* Encephalopathy
* Anemia
* ESLD

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Intensive care unit (ICU) care
* Antibiotics for sepsis
* Diuretics for fluid management
* Proton pump inhibitors for gastric protection
* Anticonvulsants for seizure prophylaxis
* Liver disease treatment with lactulose and rifaximin
* Close monitoring of vital signs, laboratory results, and medical conditions

The patient's disposition is pending improvement of respiratory status.

 SUBDURAL HEMORRHAGE (SDH)
   46M with ESLD c/b ascites, varices and encephalopathy; course
   complicated by intraparenchymal bleed, pneumonia, encephalopathy and
   current hypoxemia.
   .
   # Coagulopathy: [**1-12**] hepatic dysfunction, mild DIC on admission. Now
   holding off on repleting coagulation factors and blood products given
   stable over several days.  Minimal bleeding with suctioning.  On [**11-23**]
   patient had 2 units PRBC transfused without appropriate increase in
   hct, but no clear source of bleeding. CT head, torso yesterday ([**11-24**])
   showed no source of bleeding.
   - daily coags, HCT
   - transfuse as necessary
   .
   # Hypoxemia, fevers: Likely pneumonia.  Patient growing enterobacter
   cloacae which is pan-sensitive.  Continues to spike, however, despite
   broad coverage with antibiotics.  ABG demonstrates respiratory acidosis
   with metabolic alkalosis.  Acute incident today was in the context of
   worsening secretions; could have had mucous plugging.  In addition
   enterobacter has inducible resistance, perhaps the patient is no longer
   responding to the therapy. s/p extubation on [**11-21**].
   - ID consult, follow up recs
   - d/c Vanc and Flagyl
   - Continue Meropenem x14 day course, D1 = [**11-21**], d/c after [**12-6**]
   .
   # Hypernatremia:  Monitoring Na closely.
   - Increased free water flushes to 250mL Q4h
   - check pm lytes
   .
   #. Head Bleed s/p Fall: Occurred on [**2156-11-11**] and in setting of liver
   disease-related coagulopathy. Repeat scans show no significant changes
   ([**11-13**] and [**11-16**]) and neuro exam stable as above.
   - cont dilantin for seizure ppx, follow levels; per neurosurgery, pt
   will need to continue on dilantin until his h/s f/u in 1 mo w. head CT
   - daily neurology exams, follow INR and CBC daily
   - fall precautions, low bed
   - f/u plastics recs
   .
   #. Altered mental status: Likely secondary to hypoxia Improving. Was
   secondary to intraparenchymal hemorrhage, and hepatic encephalopathy.
   The patient has known decompensated liver disease with a previous
   history of encephalopathy.
   - cont lactulose and rifaximin ([**2-12**] BM per day)
   .
   #. Anemia: Likely due to head wound bleeding.
   - Daily HCTs, coags as above
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Will monitor NGT output for bleeding
   .
   #. ESLD: No viral etiologies per OSH records. Most likely related to
   EtOH. Patient had EtOH level on admission. Pt also has long standing
   ductal dilitation. MELD is currently 26. In records that has varices
   though unclear what or if esophageal.
   - cont lactulose and rifaximin
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - trend MELD scores
   .
   #. Transverse Process Fractures: Per neurosurgery are non-operative.
   Does not need cervical collar or log roll precautions.
   - Follow-up with Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 363**] in 4 weeks with a non-contrast head  CT.
   Call [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8464**] to schedule an appointment on the [**Location (un) 9850**] of the
   [**Hospital Unit Name 9838**] - [**Hospital Unit Name 9839**].
   .
   #. Shallow Toe Ulcer: Podiatry saw and signed off. Likely mild
   cellulitis treated with broad spec abx. Needs out pt f/u
   - make outpt f/u apt
   .
   # FEN: Follow nutrition recommendations. Start tubefeeds, 250cc free
   water flushes q4h. Replete lytes prn.
   # PPX: PPI IV BID for now assuming there are varices/gastritis, no
   heparin, bowel regimen, venodynes
   # CODE: Full code.
   # Access: PICC line c/s placed.
   .

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications are noted:

Summary:

The patient is a 46-year-old male with end-stage liver disease (ESLD) and cirrhosis, who has been admitted to the ICU with altered mental status, respiratory failure, and fever of unknown origin. He has a history of intraparenchymal bleed, pneumonia, and encephalopathy. The patient has been treated with antibiotics, and his secretions have been managed. He has also been receiving lactulose and rifaximin for his liver disease.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a significant concern, and he requires ongoing management of his oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever and worsening secretions suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and death.
3. Hepatic Encephalopathy: The patient's ESLD and cirrhosis increase his risk of developing hepatic encephalopathy, which could worsen his altered mental status and increase his risk of complications.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient's history of coagulopathy and recent bleeding from his head wound increase his risk of bleeding complications.
5. Infection: The patient's growth of Enterobacter cloacae and his continued fever suggest the possibility of ongoing infection, which could lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
6. Hypoxemia: The patient's hypoxemia is a significant concern, and he requires ongoing management of his oxygenation and ventilation.
7. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia is a potential complication of his liver disease and requires ongoing monitoring and management.
8. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status is a significant concern, and he requires ongoing management of his airway, breathing, and circulation.
9. Head Bleed: The patient's recent head bleed is a significant concern, and he requires ongoing monitoring for signs of bleeding complications.
10. ESLD: The patient's ESLD is a significant underlying condition that increases his risk of complications and death.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics and antifungal therapy to manage the patient's suspected infection.
2. Monitor the patient's oxygenation and ventilation closely to manage his respiratory failure.
3. Monitor the patient's coagulation profile and bleeding complications closely.
4. Monitor the patient's liver function tests and albumin levels to manage his ESLD.
5. Consider consulting with a liver specialist to optimize the patient's management.
6. Monitor the patient's mental status and airway, breathing, and circulation closely to manage his altered mental status.
7. Monitor the patient's head wound and bleeding complications closely.
8. Consider consulting with a neurosurgeon to manage the patient's head bleed.
9. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and manage his hypernatremia.
10. Consider consulting with a nephrologist to manage the patient's hypernatremia.

Summary:

The patient is a 47-year-old man with a history of ETOH cirrhosis, recurrent encephalopathy, and prolonged hospitalization, which has led to aspiration pneumonitis, fall, and intracranial hemorrhage. He is currently in the ICU, where he has been experiencing altered mental status, respiratory distress, and gross fluid overload. He is at risk for aspiration, altered airway clearance, and cough, and his overall prognosis is very poor due to his chronic illness.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress and inability to protect his airway increase his risk of respiratory failure, which could lead to respiratory arrest.
2. Aspiration: The patient's altered mental status and inability to protect his airway make him at high risk for aspiration, which could lead to pneumonia and other complications.
3. Sepsis: The patient's fever and unknown origin of his fever increase his risk of developing sepsis, which could lead to organ failure and death.
4. Liver failure: The patient's cirrhosis and chronic illness increase his risk of liver failure, which could lead to coagulopathy, bleeding, and other complications.
5. Intracranial hemorrhage: The patient's subdural hemorrhage is a significant risk factor for further bleeding and neurological complications.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient's fluid overload and chronic illness increase his risk of cardiac complications, such as heart failure and arrhythmias.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's cirrhosis and chronic illness increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, which could lead to hemorrhagic shock and death.
8. Infection: The patient's compromised immune system and chronic illness increase his risk of developing infections, which could lead to sepsis and other complications.

 FEVER, UNKNOWN ORIGIN (FUO, HYPERTHERMIA, PYREXIA)

 SUBDURAL HEMORRHAGE (SDH)
   46M with ESLD c/b ascites, varices and encephalopathy; course
   complicated by intraparenchymal bleed, pneumonia, encephalopathy and
   current hypoxemia.
   .
   # Hypoxemia, fevers: Likely pneumonia.  Patient growing enterobacter
   cloacae which is pan-sensitive.  Continues to spike, however, despite
   broad coverage with antibiotics.  ABG demonstrates respiratory acidosis
   with metabolic alkalosis.  Acute incident today was in the context of
   worsening secretions; could have had mucous plugging.  In addition
   enterobacter has inducible resistance, perhaps the patient is no longer
   responding to the therapy. s/p extubation on [**11-21**].
   - ID consult, follow up recs
   - d/c Vanc and Flagyl
   - Continue Meropenem x14 day course, D1 = [**11-21**], d/c after [**12-6**]
   - Lasix prn as pt
s respiratory status and hypoxia improved with
   aggressive diuresis
   - Wean PEEP as tolerated.
   .
   # Hypernatremia:  Monitoring Na closely.
   - Started D5 at 190cc/hr x 2L, pt
s free water deficit is 3.3L
   - check pm lytes
   .
   # Coagulopathy: [**1-12**] hepatic dysfunction, mild DIC on admission. Now
   holding off on repleting coagulation factors and blood products given
   stable over several days.  Minimal bleeding with suctioning.  On [**11-23**]
   patient had 2 units PRBC transfused without appropriate increase in
   hct, but no clear source of bleeding. CT head, torso yesterday ([**11-24**])
   showed no source of bleeding.
   - daily coags, HCT
   - transfuse as necessary
   .
   #. Head Bleed s/p Fall: Occurred on [**2156-11-11**] and in setting of liver
   disease-related coagulopathy. Repeat scans show no significant changes
   ([**11-13**] and [**11-16**]) and neuro exam stable as above.
   - cont dilantin for seizure ppx, follow levels; per neurosurgery, pt
   will need to continue on dilantin until his h/s f/u in 1 mo w. head CT
   - daily neurology exams, follow INR and CBC daily
   - fall precautions, low bed
   - f/u plastics recs
   .
   #. Altered mental status: Likely secondary to hypoxia--Improving. Was
   secondary to intraparenchymal hemorrhage, and hepatic encephalopathy.
   The patient has known decompensated liver disease with a previous
   history of encephalopathy.
   - cont lactulose and rifaximin ([**2-12**] BM per day)
   .
   #. Anemia: Stable.
   - Daily HCTs, coags as above
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Will monitor NGT output for bleeding
   .
   #. ESLD: No viral etiologies per OSH records. Most likely related to
   EtOH. Patient had EtOH level on admission. Pt also has long standing
   ductal dilitation. MELD is 28 ([**11-29**]). In records that has varices
   though unclear what or if esophageal.
   - cont lactulose and rifaximin
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - trend MELD scores
   .
   #. Transverse Process Fractures: Per neurosurgery are non-operative.
   Does not need cervical collar or log roll precautions.
   - Follow-up with Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 363**] in 4 weeks with a non-contrast head CT.
   Call [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8464**] to schedule an appointment on the [**Location (un) 9850**] of the
   [**Hospital Unit Name 9838**] - [**Hospital Unit Name 9839**].
   .
   #. Shallow Toe Ulcer: Podiatry saw and signed off. Likely mild
   cellulitis treated with broad spec abx. Needs out pt f/u
   - make outpt f/u apt
   .
   # FEN: Follow nutrition recommendations. Start tubefeeds, 250cc free
   water flushes q4h. Replete lytes prn.
   # PPX: PPI IV BID for now assuming there are varices/gastritis, no
   heparin, bowel regimen, venodynes
   # CODE: Full code.
   # Access: PICC line c/s placed.
   .
   # CONTACT: [**Name (NI) 83**] formal HCP. Brother has been signing consents. [**Name (NI) 2255**]
   (brother) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9357**]. Other family numbers: [**Name (NI) 1515**] (mother) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9642**], and [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9359**]. Girlfriend [**Name (NI) 7080**] [**Name (NI) 9340**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9341**] has been
   main decision maker. GF was on the way to getting HCP status when
   recent fall happened.
   # Dispo:  ICU pending improvement of respiratory status.

   enterobacter has inducible resistance, perhaps the patient is no longer
   responding to the therapy. s/p extubation on [**11-21**].
   - ID consult, follow up recs
   - d/c Vanc and Flagyl
   - Continue Meropenem x14 day course, D1 = [**11-21**], d/c after [**12-6**]
   - Lasix prn as pt
s respiratory status and hypoxia improved with
   aggressive diuresis
   - Wean PEEP as tolerated.
   .
   # Hypernatremia:  Monitoring Na closely.
   - Started D5 at 190cc/hr x 2L, pt
s free water deficit is 3.3L
   - check pm lytes
   .
   # Coagulopathy: [**1-12**] hepatic dysfunction, mild DIC on admission. Now
   holding off on repleting coagulation factors and blood products given
   stable over several days.  Minimal bleeding with suctioning.  On [**11-23**]
   patient had 2 units PRBC transfused without appropriate increase in
   hct, but no clear source of bleeding. CT head, torso yesterday ([**11-24**])
   showed no source of bleeding.
   - daily coags, HCT
   - transfuse as necessary
   .
   #. Head Bleed s/p Fall: Occurred on [**2156-11-11**] and in setting of liver
   disease-related coagulopathy. Repeat scans show no significant changes
   ([**11-13**] and [**11-16**]) and neuro exam stable as above.
   - cont dilantin for seizure ppx, follow levels; per neurosurgery, pt
   will need to continue on dilantin until his h/s f/u in 1 mo w. head CT
   - daily neurology exams, follow INR and CBC daily
   - fall precautions, low bed
   - f/u plastics recs
   .
   #. Altered mental status: Likely secondary to hypoxia--Improving. Was
   secondary to intraparenchymal hemorrhage, and hepatic encephalopathy.
   The patient has known decompensated liver disease with a previous
   history of encephalopathy.
   - cont lactulose and rifaximin ([**2-12**] BM per day)
   .
   #. Anemia: Stable.
   - Daily HCTs, coags as above
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Will monitor NGT output for bleeding
   .
   #. ESLD: No viral etiologies per OSH records. Most likely related to
   EtOH. Patient had EtOH level on admission. Pt also has long standing
   ductal dilitation. MELD is 28 ([**11-29**]). In records that has varices
   though unclear what or if esophageal.
   - cont lactulose and rifaximin
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - trend MELD scores
   .
   #. Transverse Process Fractures: Per neurosurgery are non-operative.
   Does not need cervical collar or log roll precautions.
   - Follow-up with Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 363**] in 4 weeks with a non-contrast head CT.
   Call [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8464**] to schedule an appointment on the [**Location (un) 9850**] of the
   [**Hospital Unit Name 9838**] - [**Hospital Unit Name 9839**].
   .
   #. Shallow Toe Ulcer: Podiatry saw and signed off. Likely mild
   cellulitis treated with broad spec abx. Needs out pt f/u
   - make outpt f/u apt
   .
   # FEN: Follow nutrition recommendations. Start tubefeeds, 250cc free
   water flushes q4h. Replete lytes prn.
   # PPX: PPI IV BID for now assuming there are varices/gastritis, no
   heparin, bowel regimen, venodynes
   # CODE: Full code.
   # Access: PICC line c/s placed.
   .
   # CONTACT: [**Name (NI) 83**] formal HCP. Brother has been signing consents. [**Name (NI) 2255**]
   (brother) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9357**]. Other family numbers: [**Name (NI) 1515**] (mother) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9642**], and [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9359**]. Girlfriend [**Name (NI) 7080**] [**Name (NI) 9340**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9341**] has been
   main decision maker. GF was on the way to getting HCP status when
   recent fall happened.
   # Dispo:  ICU pending improvement of respiratory status.<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 46-year-old male with ESLD (cirrhosis of the liver, alcoholic), respiratory failure, and a subdural hematoma. The patient is currently intubated and receiving invasive ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38.2°C (100.8°F)
* Heart rate: 88 bpm
* Blood pressure: 116/47 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 14 inspirations per minute
* SpO2: 96%
* Weight: 90.5 kg (current), 80.8 kg (admission)

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 6.7 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 6.6 g/dL
* Platelet count: 68 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
* Sodium: 149 mEq/L
* Potassium: 4.1 mEq/L
* Albumin: 2.7 g/dL
* Lactic acid: 3.3 mmol/L
* Calcium: 9.3 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 4.5 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* CXR (chest X-ray): bilateral pleural effusion, left greater than right, with bibasilar opacity left greater than right, which could reflect basilar atelectasis. The ET and NG tubes are in unchanged locations.

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Altered mental status (not delirium)
* Airway, inability to protect (risk for aspiration, altered gag, airway clearance, cough)
* Fever, unknown origin (FUO, hyperthermia, pyrexia)
* Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS)
* Subdural hematoma (SDH)

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Antibiotics for pneumonia
* Diuresis for fluid overload
* Monitoring of sodium levels
* Coagulopathy management
* Head injury management
* Altered mental status management
* ESLD management
* Transverse process fractures management
* Shallow toe ulcer management
* Nutrition management
* Bowel regimen
* Venodynes

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure
* Sepsis
* Organ failure (liver, kidneys, etc.)
* Increased intracranial pressure
* Seizures
* Bleeding complications
* Infection
* Cardiovascular complications

The patient's disposition is ICU pending improvement of respiratory status.

The patient's current medical conditions include:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 47-year-old man with ETOH cirrhosis, recurrent encephalopathy, intubated for respiratory distress, and unable to protect his airway. He has a history of liver cirrhosis, recurrent encephalopathy, and is currently intubated for respiratory distress.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38.2°C (100.8°F) with a current temperature of 37.9°C (100.3°F)
* Heart rate: 90 beats per minute with a range of 81-97 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 120/56 mmHg with a range of 77-130/38-82 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 15 breaths per minute with a range of 14-23 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 97%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 6.6 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 38 K/uL
* Platelet count: 68 K/uL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 96 mg/dL
* Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
* Glucose: 184 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 3.3 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.7 g/dL
* LDH: 375 IU/L
* Calcium: 9.3 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 4.5 mg/dL

The patient's physical examination shows:

* General appearance: No acute distress, thin
* Eyes/conjunctiva: PERRL
* Head, ears, nose, throat: Normocephalic
* Lymphatic: Cervical WNL
* Cardiovascular: Normal S1 and S2 sounds
* Peripheral vascular: Right radial pulse not assessed, left radial pulse not assessed, right DP pulse not assessed, left DP pulse not assessed
* Respiratory/chest: Clear breath sounds
* Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, bowel sounds present
* Extremities: Right lower extremity edema: Trace, left lower extremity edema: Trace
* Skin: Warm
* Neurologic: Not attentive, does not follow simple commands, responds to stimuli, movement not assessed, tone not assessed

The patient has a number of potential medical complications, including:

* Respiratory failure: Unable to protect his airway, at risk for aspiration, altered gag, airway clearance, and cough.
* Coagulopathy: Stable, but at risk for bleeding complications.
* Intracranial hemorrhage: On dilantin, at risk for bleeding complications.
* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): On meropenem, at risk for antibiotic-resistant infections.
* Subdural hemorrhage: At risk for bleeding complications.
* Fever of unknown origin (FUO): At risk for sepsis and multi-organ failure.

The patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat these potential complications. He should be closely monitored for signs of respiratory distress, coagulopathy, and bleeding complications. The patient's antibiotic regimen should be adjusted based on the results of his microbiology cultures. He should also be considered for tracheostomy if aggressive care is desired.

Summary:

The patient is a 46-year-old male with end-stage liver disease (ESLD) and cirrhosis, who is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation in the ICU. He has a history of intraparenchymal bleed, pneumonia, encephalopathy, and has been intubated three times without improvement in his mental status. The patient has a fever of 101.3°F, and his mental status is altered, but not delirious. He has a history of falls, and his head CT scan shows no significant changes.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, but his hypoxemia persists, and he has respiratory acidosis with metabolic alkalosis. His ABG results show a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 174, which suggests that he is not responding to therapy. He has a history of Enterobacter cloacae growth, which is pan-sensitive, but he continues to spike fevers despite broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage.

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level. His coagulation studies show mild disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) on admission, but it has since stabilized.

The patient's plan is to continue broad-spectrum antibiotics for 14 days, and to consider paracentesis for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) if his condition declines. He will also require tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement for nutrition.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemia persists, and his respiratory acidosis with metabolic alkalosis may worsen if his condition does not improve.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever and leukocytosis may indicate sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death if not treated promptly.
3. Bleeding: The patient's coagulopathy and history of falls may increase his risk of bleeding, which can be life-threatening if not managed promptly.
4. Encephalopathy: The patient's altered mental status may worsen if his liver function does not improve, which can lead to coma and death.
5. Infection: The patient's history of pneumonia and growth of Enterobacter cloacae may increase his risk of infection, which can lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
6. Malnutrition: The patient's ESLD and history of falls may increase his risk of malnutrition, which can worsen his overall condition and increase his risk of complications.

It is essential to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 46-year-old male with end-stage liver disease (ESLD), cirrhosis, and ascites, who has been admitted to the ICU with altered mental status, respiratory failure, and fever of unknown origin.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 101.3°F (38.5°C)
* Heart rate: 96 bpm
* Blood pressure: 120/49 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 14 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 96%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 6.8 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 7.3 g/dL
* Platelet count: 43 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.6 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 37 mg/dL
* Sodium: 165 mg/dL
* Potassium: 3.6 mEq/L
* Chloride: 109 mEq/L
* Albumin: 2.7 g/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.9 mmol/L

The patient has been intubated three times during this hospitalization, without improvement in his mental status. The patient's airway is at risk, and he is likely to require a tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement.

The patient's respiratory status is worsening, with increasing respiratory acidosis and metabolic alkalosis. The patient's hypernatremia is being monitored closely, and he is receiving aggressive diuresis to manage his fluid status.

The patient has a history of liver disease-related coagulopathy and has had a subdural hemorrhage in the past. He is currently being monitored for bleeding and is receiving anticoagulation therapy.

The patient's altered mental status is likely secondary to hypoxia, and he is being treated with lactulose and rifaximin to manage his encephalopathy.

The patient has a shallow toe ulcer that is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics and will require follow-up with a podiatrist.

The patient's family is being updated on his condition, and a meeting has been scheduled for Wednesday to discuss his goals of care and disposition.

Potential medical complications that can arise in this patient include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is worsening, and he is at risk for further respiratory failure.
* Infection: The patient has a fever of unknown origin and is at risk for developing a secondary infection.
* Bleeding: The patient has a history of liver disease-related coagulopathy and is at risk for bleeding.
* Encephalopathy: The patient's altered mental status is likely secondary to hypoxia, and he is at risk for further encephalopathy.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels are elevated, and he is at risk for further hypernatremia.
* Dehydration: The patient is receiving aggressive diuresis, and he is at risk for dehydration.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 47-year-old male with ETOH cirrhosis, recurrent aspiration, and respiratory failure. He has been admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and has a fever of 101.3°F. The patient has a history of cirrhosis, liver disease, and respiratory failure.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 101.3°F
* Heart rate: 92 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 112/44 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 14 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 94%
* Height: 72 inches
* Weight: 90.5 kg (admission weight: 80.8 kg)

The patient has been receiving various medications, including antibiotics, antacids, and diuretics. He has also been receiving respiratory support, including oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation.

The patient's laboratory results show the following:

* White blood cell count: 6.8 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 7.3 g/dL
* Platelet count: 43 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.6 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 38 mg/dL
* Glucose: 92 mg/dL

The patient's physical examination shows the following:

* Eyes and conjunctiva: PERRL
* Head, ears, nose, and throat: Normocephalic
* Lymphatic: Cervical WNL
* Cardiovascular: S1 and S2 normal
* Peripheral vascular: Right radial pulse not assessed, left radial pulse not assessed, right DP pulse not assessed, left DP pulse not assessed
* Respiratory and chest: Clear breath sounds
* Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, bowel sounds present
* Extremities: Right lower extremity edema 2+, left lower extremity edema 2+
* Skin: Warm, jaundiced
* Neurologic: Responds to stimuli, movement not assessed, tone not assessed

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Altered mental status (not delirium)
* Airway, inability to protect (risk for aspiration, altered gag, airway clearance, cough)
* Cirrhosis of liver, alcoholic
* Fever, unknown origin (FUO, hyperthermia, pyrexia)
* Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS)
* Subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he is at risk for further respiratory failure.
* Fever: The patient's fever is of unknown origin and may be a sign of infection or other underlying condition.
* Cirrhosis: The patient's cirrhosis may lead to further complications, such as liver failure or portal hypertension.
* Subdural hemorrhage: The patient's subdural hemorrhage may lead to further complications, such as increased intracranial pressure or brain herniation.
* Aspiration: The patient's inability to protect his airway may lead to aspiration, which can cause further respiratory failure or other complications.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and to improve his respiratory status.

   46M with ESLD c/b ascites, varices and encephalopathy; course
   complicated by intraparenchymal bleed, pneumonia, encephalopathy and
   current hypoxemia.
   .
   # Hypoxemia, fevers: Likely pneumonia.  Patient growing enterobacter
   cloacae which is pan-sensitive.  Continues to spike, however, despite
   broad coverage with antibiotics.  ABG demonstrates respiratory acidosis
   with metabolic alkalosis.  Acute incident today was in the context of
   worsening secretions; could have had mucous plugging.  In addition
   enterobacter has inducible resistance, perhaps the patient is no longer
   responding to the therapy. s/p extubation on [**11-21**]. Pt has been
   intubated 3 times this hospitalization, without improvement in his
   mental status.   He will need trach/PEG placement, as at this point it
   is unlikely that his mental status will improve such that he will be
   able to protect his airway.
   - Surgery consulted, will place Trach tomorrow ([**12-2**]), and PEG also,
   if pt afebrile.
   - New fevers but unknown source. Sent bcx, ucx, sputum cx; cxr from
   today does not show evidence of infiltrate; need to follow up cultures.
   Will send C. diff.
   - Continue Meropenem x14 day course, D1 = [**11-21**], d/c after [**12-6**]
   - If pt clinically declines, consider paracentesis for SBP
   - Arrange trach placement
   - ID consult, follow up recs
   - Lasix prn as pt
s respiratory status and hypoxia improved with
   aggressive diuresis
   - Wean PEEP as tolerated.
   .
   # Hypernatremia:  Monitoring Na closely. Urine lytes do not suggest
   SIADH.
   - check PM sodium
   - Continue free water flushes; will continue D5 given cont
   hypernatremia
   .
   Stable/Non-active Issues:
   .
   # Coagulopathy: [**1-12**] hepatic dysfunction, mild DIC on admission. Now
   holding off on repleting coagulation factors and blood products given
   stable over several days.  Minimal bleeding with suctioning.  On [**11-23**]
   patient had 2 units PRBC transfused without appropriate increase in
   hct, but no clear source of bleeding. CT head, torso yesterday ([**11-24**])
   showed no source of bleeding.
   - daily coags, HCT
   - transfuse as necessary
   .
   #. Head Bleed s/p Fall: Occurred on [**2156-11-11**] and in setting of liver
   disease-related coagulopathy. Repeat scans show no significant changes
   ([**11-13**] and [**11-16**]) and neuro exam stable as above.
   - cont dilantin for seizure ppx, follow levels; per neurosurgery, pt
   will need to continue on dilantin until his h/s f/u in 1 mo w. head CT
   - daily neurology exams, follow INR and CBC daily
   - fall precautions, low bed
   - f/u plastics recs
   .
   #. Altered mental status: Likely secondary to hypoxia--Improving. Was
   secondary to intraparenchymal hemorrhage, and hepatic encephalopathy.
   The patient has known decompensated liver disease with a previous
   history of encephalopathy.
   - cont lactulose and rifaximin ([**2-12**] BM per day)
   .
   #. Anemia: Stable.
   - Daily HCTs, coags as above
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Will monitor NGT output for bleeding
   .
   #. ESLD: No viral etiologies per OSH records. Most likely related to
   EtOH. Patient had EtOH level on admission. Pt also has long standing
   ductal dilitation. MELD is 28 ([**11-29**]). In records that has varices
   though unclear what or if esophageal.
   - cont lactulose and rifaximin
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - trend MELD scores
   .
   #. Transverse Process Fractures: Per neurosurgery are non-operative.
   Does not need cervical collar or log roll precautions.
   - Follow-up with Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 363**] in 4 weeks with a non-contrast head CT.
   Call [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8464**] to schedule an appointment on the [**Location (un) 9850**] of the
   [**Hospital Unit Name 9838**] - [**Hospital Unit Name 9839**].
   .
   #. Shallow Toe Ulcer: Podiatry saw and signed off. Likely mild
   cellulitis treated with broad spec abx. Needs out pt f/u
   - make outpt f/u apt
   .
   # FEN: Follow nutrition recommendations. Start tubefeeds, 250cc free
   water flushes q4h. Considering PEG placement. Replete lytes prn.
   # PPX: PPI IV BID for now assuming there are varices/gastritis, no
   heparin, bowel regimen, venodynes
   # CODE: Full code.
   # Access: PICC line c/s placed.
   .
   # CONTACT: [**Name (NI) 9995**] mother [**Name (NI) 1515**] is the next of [**Doctor First Name **] and the person to
   call for consents/updates. ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 9996**] and [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9997**]. Other
   family numbers: [**Name (NI) 2255**] (brother) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9357**]. Girlfriend [**Name (NI) 7080**] [**Name (NI) 9340**]
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9341**] (not the HCP).
   # Dispo:  ICU pending improvement of respiratory status

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

* The patient is a 46-year-old male with end-stage liver disease (ESLD) and a history of alcoholism, who has been admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, subdural hematoma, and altered mental status.
* The patient has been febrile since admission, with a temperature ranging from 100.6°F to 101.6°F.
* The patient has been treated with antibiotics, including meropenem, but has continued to spike fevers, which may indicate resistance to the antibiotic.
* The patient has a history of pneumonia, and a CXR from today shows large bilateral pleural effusions and bibasilar atelectasis.
* The patient's respiratory status has improved with aggressive diuresis, but he still requires mechanical ventilation.
* The patient has a coagulopathy, which is being managed with daily coagulation factor replacement and blood product transfusions.
* The patient has a head bleed from a fall on November 11, which is being monitored with daily neurology exams and follow-up imaging.
* The patient has altered mental status, which is likely secondary to hypoxia, intraparenchymal hemorrhage, and hepatic encephalopathy.
* The patient has anemia, which is being managed with daily HCTs and coags.
* The patient has ESLD, which is being managed with lactulose and rifaximin.

Potential medical complications that may arise from the patient's condition include:

* Pneumonia, which may worsen the patient's respiratory status and increase the risk of respiratory failure.
* Sepsis, which may develop from the patient's febrile state and increase the risk of organ dysfunction.
* Respiratory failure, which may occur if the patient's respiratory status worsens or if the patient develops respiratory acidosis.
* Coagulopathy, which may increase the risk of bleeding and hemorrhage.
* Head injury, which may worsen the patient's neurological status and increase the risk of intracranial hypertension.
* Hepatic encephalopathy, which may worsen the patient's mental status and increase the risk of coma.
* Malnutrition, which may occur if the patient is unable to tolerate enteral nutrition or if the patient's nutritional needs are not being met.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue meropenem for 14 days, with a goal of improving the patient's respiratory status and reducing the risk of sepsis.
* Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust ventilation settings as necessary.
* Continue coagulation factor replacement and blood product transfusions to manage the patient's coagulopathy.
* Monitor the patient's neurological status closely and adjust treatment as necessary.
* Continue lactulose and rifaximin to manage the patient's ESLD.
* Monitor the patient's nutritional status closely and adjust enteral nutrition as necessary.
* Consider PEG placement to improve the patient's nutritional status and reduce the risk of malnutrition.

   if pt afebrile. Will need 1U Plt and 4U FFP prior to surgery.
   - Continue Meropenem x14 day course, D1 = [**11-21**], d/c after [**12-6**]
   - If pt clinically declines, consider paracentesis for SBP
 however pt
   is being covered for SBP with meropenem.
   - Arrange trach placement
   - ID consult, follow up recs
   - Lasix prn as pt
s respiratory status and hypoxia improved with
   aggressive diuresis; but holding for now given pt
s hypernatremia.
   - Wean PEEP as tolerated.
   .
   # Fever: - New fevers but unknown source. Sent bcx, ucx, sputum cx; cxr
   from today does not show evidence of infiltrate; need to follow up
   cultures.  Will evaluate for non-infectious causes of fever while
   continuing to treat for VAP.
   - Will send C. diff.
   - Will obtain RUQ US to eval for cholecystitis
   - Will start empiric Vanco coverage
   - Will check lipase to eval for pancreatitis, as non-infectious cause
   of fever
   - Continue Meropenem x14 day course, D1 = [**11-21**], d/c after [**12-6**]
   - If pt clinically declines, consider paracentesis for SBP
 however pt
   is being covered for SBP with meropenem.
   - ID consult, follow up recs
   - If pt continues to spike, could consider dedicated CT sinus to eval
   for sinusitis.
   .
   # Hypernatremia:  Monitoring Na closely. Urine lytes do not suggest DI.
    Suspect hypernatremia is due to pt not having tube feeds x 3 days,
   on-going tx with lactulose, and aggressive diuresis on the floor.
   - Continue free water flushes; will continue D5 given cont
   hypernatremia
   - check PM sodium
   .
   Stable/Non-active Issues:
   .
   # Coagulopathy: [**1-12**] hepatic dysfunction, mild DIC on admission. Now
   holding off on repleting coagulation factors and blood products given
   stable over several days.  Minimal bleeding with suctioning.  On [**11-23**]
   patient had 2 units PRBC transfused without appropriate increase in
   hct, but no clear source of bleeding. CT head, torso yesterday ([**11-24**])
   showed no source of bleeding.
   - daily coags, HCT
   - transfuse as necessary
   .
   #. Head Bleed s/p Fall: Occurred on [**2156-11-11**] and in setting of liver
   disease-related coagulopathy. Repeat scans show no significant changes
   ([**11-13**] and [**11-16**]) and neuro exam stable as above.
   - cont dilantin for seizure ppx, follow levels; per neurosurgery, pt
   will need to continue on dilantin until his h/s f/u in 1 mo w. head CT
   - daily neurology exams, follow INR and CBC daily
   - fall precautions, low bed
   - f/u plastics recs
   .
   #. Altered mental status: Likely secondary to hypoxia--Improving. Was
   secondary to intraparenchymal hemorrhage, and hepatic encephalopathy.
   The patient has known decompensated liver disease with a previous
   history of encephalopathy.
   - cont lactulose and rifaximin ([**2-12**] BM per day)
   .
   #. Anemia: Stable.
   - Daily HCTs, coags as above
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Will monitor NGT output for bleeding
   .
   #. ESLD: No viral etiologies per OSH records. Most likely related to
   EtOH. Patient had EtOH level on admission. Pt also has long standing
   ductal dilitation. MELD is 28 ([**11-29**]). In records that has varices
   though unclear what or if esophageal.
   - cont lactulose and rifaximin
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - trend MELD scores
   .
   #. Transverse Process Fractures: Per neurosurgery are non-operative.
   Does not need cervical collar or log roll precautions.
   - Follow-up with Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 363**] in 4 weeks with a non-contrast head CT.
   Call [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8464**] to schedule an appointment on the [**Location (un) 9850**] of the
   [**Hospital Unit Name 9838**] - [**Hospital Unit Name 9839**].
   .
   #. Shallow Toe Ulcer: Podiatry saw and signed off. Likely mild
   cellulitis treated with broad spec abx. Needs out pt f/u
   - make outpt f/u apt
   .
   # FEN: Follow nutrition recommendations. Start tubefeeds, 300cc free
   water flushes q4h. Replete lytes prn. NPO after midnight for PEG
   placement.
   # PPX: PPI IV BID for now assuming there are varices/gastritis, no
   heparin, bowel regimen, venodynes
   # CODE: Full code.
   # Access: PICC line c/s placed.
   .
   # CONTACT: [**Name (NI) 9995**] mother [**Name (NI) 1515**] is the next of [**Doctor First Name **] and the person to
   call for consents/updates. ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 9996**] and [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9997**]. Other
   family numbers: [**Name (NI) 2255**] (brother) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9357**]. Girlfriend [**Name (NI) 7080**] [**Name (NI) 9340**]
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9341**] (not the HCP).
   # Dispo:  ICU pending PEG/trach placement, begin screening pt for rehab
   (will need LTAC)<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Summary:

The patient is a 46-year-old male with a history of cirrhosis of the liver, alcohol-induced, who is currently intubated and in the ICU due to respiratory failure, subdural hematoma, and altered mental status. The patient has a history of falls, including one that resulted in a head bleed, and has been treated with anticonvulsants. The patient has also had a history of encephalopathy and is currently being treated with lactulose and rifaximin.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation.
* Subdural hematoma: The patient has a subdural hematoma that was diagnosed on imaging studies.
* Altered mental status: The patient has altered mental status, which is likely secondary to hypoxia, intraparenchymal hemorrhage, and hepatic encephalopathy.
* Fever: The patient has a fever of 101.6°F, which is of unknown origin.
* Hypernatremia: The patient has hypernatremia, which is being treated with free water flushes and diuresis.
* Coagulopathy: The patient has a coagulopathy, which is being treated with blood products and anticoagulants.
* Anemia: The patient has anemia, which is being treated with blood transfusions.
* ESLD: The patient has end-stage liver disease, which is being treated with lactulose and rifaximin.

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is at risk for further respiratory failure due to his underlying lung disease and the need for mechanical ventilation.
* Subdural hematoma: The patient is at risk for further bleeding and potential worsening of his subdural hematoma.
* Altered mental status: The patient is at risk for further decline in his mental status due to his underlying liver disease and potential worsening of his subdural hematoma.
* Fever: The patient is at risk for further fever and potential worsening of his underlying infection.
* Hypernatremia: The patient is at risk for further hypernatremia and potential worsening of his underlying liver disease.
* Coagulopathy: The patient is at risk for further bleeding and potential worsening of his coagulopathy.
* Anemia: The patient is at risk for further anemia and potential worsening of his underlying liver disease.
* ESLD: The patient is at risk for further decline in his liver function and potential worsening of his end-stage liver disease.

Recommendations:

* Continue mechanical ventilation and respiratory support as needed.
* Monitor the patient's subdural hematoma and potential for further bleeding.
* Continue treatment for altered mental status, including lactulose and rifaximin.
* Monitor the patient's fever and potential for further infection.
* Continue treatment for hypernatremia, including free water flushes and diuresis.
* Monitor the patient's coagulopathy and potential for further bleeding.
* Monitor the patient's anemia and potential for further decline in his liver function.
* Continue treatment for ESLD, including lactulose and rifaximin.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for further complications and potential decline in his condition. Close monitoring and aggressive treatment are necessary to prevent further complications and improve his outcome.

Summary:

The patient is a 47-year-old man with ETOH cirrhosis, multiple falls, and awaiting T+G. He has been febrile, with a temperature of 101.6°F (38.7°C). The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, FiO2 50%, and PEEP 5 cmH2O. He has altered mental status, unable to protect his airway, and is at risk for aspiration. The patient has a subdural hemorrhage and cirrhosis of the liver.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he is at risk of developing respiratory failure due to his altered mental status and inability to protect his airway.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever and altered mental status may be indicative of sepsis, which could lead to multi-organ dysfunction.
3. Aspiration: The patient's inability to protect his airway increases the risk of aspiration, which could lead to pneumonia and other complications.
4. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's cirrhosis of the liver may lead to hepatic encephalopathy, which could worsen his altered mental status.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may be due to a combination of decreased intake, lasix, and lactulose causing osmotic diarrhea, which could lead to further complications if not addressed.
6. Subdural hemorrhage: The patient's subdural hemorrhage may worsen and lead to increased intracranial pressure, which could have devastating consequences.
7. Infection: The patient's fevers may be indicative of an underlying infection, which could spread and lead to further complications if not treated promptly and effectively.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust his ventilation settings as needed.
2. Administer antibiotics to cover MRSA and other potential pathogens.
3. Perform a RUQ U/S to rule out acalculous cholecystitis as a potential source of the patient's fever.
4. Consider adding vanco to cover MRSA for fevers.
5. Address the patient's hypernatremia by increasing his fluid intake and adjusting his diuretic therapy as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's subdural hemorrhage and consider further imaging or surgical intervention if necessary.
7. Consider performing a lumbar puncture to rule out meningitis or other central nervous system infections.

Summary:

The patient is a 46-year-old male with End-Stage Liver Disease (ESLD) and a history of intraparenchymal bleed, pneumonia, encephalopathy, and current hypoxemia. He has been intubated four times during his hospitalization without significant improvement in his mental status. The patient's condition is complicated by cholelithiasis, splenomegaly, and heterogeneous liver echotexture consistent with cirrhosis. He has a large right pleural effusion and ascites in the right upper quadrant.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to pneumonia, and he may require mechanical ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to organ failure.
3. Hepatic Encephalopathy: The patient's history of liver disease and current encephalopathy increase the risk of hepatic encephalopathy, which can lead to coma and death.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient's history of coagulopathy and current bleeding complications increase the risk of bleeding complications, including gastrointestinal bleeding and intracranial hemorrhage.
5. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia may worsen and lead to respiratory failure, sepsis, and other complications.
6. Cholelithiasis: The patient's cholelithiasis may lead to cholecystitis, pancreatitis, and other complications.
7. Splenomegaly: The patient's splenomegaly may lead to bleeding complications, including gastrointestinal bleeding and intracranial hemorrhage.
8. Pleural Effusion: The patient's large right pleural effusion may lead to respiratory failure and other complications.
9. Ascites: The patient's ascites may lead to abdominal compartment syndrome, respiratory failure, and other complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and provide mechanical ventilation as needed.
2. Treat the patient's pneumonia with broad-spectrum antibiotics and consider adding antifungal agents if the patient's condition worsens.
3. Monitor the patient's coagulation status and transfuse blood products as needed to prevent bleeding complications.
4. Continue to manage the patient's liver disease with lactulose and rifaximin, and consider adding other medications as needed to prevent complications.
5. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and treat any imbalances promptly to prevent complications.
6. Consider performing a dedicated CT sinus to evaluate for sinusitis in the near future.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and provide supportive care as needed to prevent further deterioration.
8. Consider performing a tracheostomy to facilitate airway management and improve the patient's quality of life.
9. Provide ongoing nutritional support and consider adding other medications as needed to prevent complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 46-year-old male with end-stage liver disease (ESLD), who has been admitted to the ICU due to worsening respiratory failure, acute liver failure, and sepsis. He has a history of alcohol use disorder and has been intubated multiple times during this hospitalization. The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and has been on mechanical ventilation for several days. He has a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 180, indicating moderate hypoxemia.
* Cardiovascular: The patient's blood pressure is 124/61 mmHg, and his heart rate is 92 bpm.
* Neurological: The patient has altered mental status, likely secondary to hypoxia, intraparenchymal hemorrhage, and hepatic encephalopathy. He has a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 8.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has ESLD with ascites, varices, and encephalopathy. He has a history of bleeding and has been treated with lactulose and rifaximin.
* Renal: The patient has hypernatremia, which is being monitored closely. His urine osmolality is normal, and his creatinine is 0.5 mg/dL.
* Coagulopathy: The patient has mild disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) and is being monitored closely for bleeding.
* Infectious: The patient has a fever of 101.2°F, and cultures are pending. He has been treated with empiric antibiotics, including vancomycin and meropenem.

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he is at risk for further deterioration.
* Sepsis: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count suggest that he may have an underlying infection.
* Coagulopathy: The patient's mild DIC and history of bleeding make him at risk for further bleeding complications.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level is elevated, which can lead to complications such as seizures, coma, and death.
* ESLD: The patient's ESLD is likely to progress, and he may require further interventions such as liver transplantation.
* Infections: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count suggest that he may have an underlying infection, which can lead to further complications.

Plan:

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications that can arise:

The patient is a 47-year-old man with cirrhosis of the liver, encephalopathy, multiple falls, intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH), and recurrent aspiration. He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to respiratory failure and has been experiencing fever, with no clear cause.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 101.2°F (38.4°C)
* Heart rate: 87 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 112/48 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 13 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 96%

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General appearance: thin, no acute distress
* Cardiovascular: normal heart sounds, no murmurs
* Respiratory: clear breath sounds, no wheezing or rales
* Abdominal: soft, non-tender, bowel sounds present
* Neurological: attentive, follows simple commands, responds to verbal stimuli, but does not follow commands

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hypernatremia (high sodium level)
* Altered mental status (not delirium)
* Elevated liver enzymes (ALT, AST, and alkaline phosphatase)
* Elevated white blood cell count
* Elevated lactate level

The patient's medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure due to recurrent aspiration
* Fever of unknown origin (FUO)
* Hypernatremia
* Altered mental status
* Cirrhosis of the liver
* Subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Tracheostomy today
* Follow-up cultures to determine the cause of fever
* Discontinuation of meropenem after 12 hours
* Lasix for diuresis due to gross fluid overload
* Reduction of dilantin dose to 100mg due to high level

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to continued aspiration
* Sepsis or septic shock due to unknown origin of fever
* Hepatic encephalopathy due to cirrhosis
* Brain edema or herniation due to SDH
* Electrolyte imbalances due to hypernatremia or dehydration
* Infection or sepsis due to indwelling lines or catheters
* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to cirrhosis or liver failure

 HYPERNATREMIA (HIGH SODIUM)
 ALTERED MENTAL STATUS (NOT DELIRIUM)
 AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,

 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 2**])
 SUBDURAL HEMORRHAGE (SDH)
   46M with ESLD c/b ascites, varices and encephalopathy; course
   complicated by intraparenchymal bleed, pneumonia, encephalopathy and
   current hypoxemia.
   .
   # Hypoxemia,: Likely pneumonia.  Patient growing enterobacter cloacae
   which is pan-sensitive.  Continues to spike, however, despite broad
   coverage with antibiotics.  ABG demonstrates respiratory acidosis with
   metabolic alkalosis.  Acute incident today was in the context of
   worsening secretions; could have had mucous plugging.  In addition
   enterobacter has inducible resistance, perhaps the patient is no longer
   responding to the therapy. s/p extubation on [**11-21**]. Pt has been
   intubated 4 times this hospitalization, without significant improvement
   in his mental status.   He will need trach/PEG placement, as at this
   point it is unlikely that his mental status will improve such that he
   will be able to protect his airway.
   - Trach planned for this AM,  will give 1U Plts, 5U FFP, 1U pRBCs prior
   - Continue Meropenem x14 day course, D1 = [**11-21**], d/c after [**12-6**]
   - Continue Vanc 1g q12h D1 = [**12-1**]
   - f/u ID recs
   - Now that hypernatremia is resolved, will start diuresis with Lasix
   again (give 40mg IV once today)
   .
   # Fever: - Unclear etiology, however will treat for possible PNA, SBP.
   Likely due to drug fever.
   - C diff neg
   - RUQ US neg for cholecystitis
   - Continue Meropenem x14 day course, D1 = [**11-21**], d/c after [**12-6**]
   - Continue Vanc 1g q12h D1 = [**12-1**]
   - Lipase nl
   - f/u ID recs
   - Consider dedicated CT sinus to eval for sinusitis in near future
   .
   # Hypernatremia:  Now resolved
   - Continue free water flushes
   - PM lytes
   .
   Stable/Non-active Issues:
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 46-year-old male with ESLD (end-stage liver disease) who has been admitted to the ICU for several weeks. The patient has a complex medical history, including cirrhosis of the liver, ascites, varices, and encephalopathy. He has had multiple episodes of bleeding, including an intraparenchymal bleed, and has been treated with blood products and coagulation factors.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. He has a tracheostomy tube in place and is receiving oxygen therapy. His ABG results show respiratory acidosis with metabolic alkalosis.
* Cardiovascular: The patient's blood pressure is stable, and he is receiving vasopressors as needed. His cardiac rhythm is sinusoidal, and he has no signs of cardiac failure.
* Neurological: The patient has altered mental status, likely secondary to hypoxia and liver encephalopathy. He is receiving lactulose and rifaximin for treatment of his encephalopathy.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has ascites and varices, and is receiving lactulose and rifaximin to treat his encephalopathy. He has also had episodes of bleeding, including an intraparenchymal bleed.
* Renal: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he is receiving diuretics to manage his fluid status.
* Hematological: The patient has anemia, and is receiving blood transfusions as needed.

The patient's laboratory results are as follows:

* WBC: 5.6-6.2 x 10^9/L
* Hct: 21.9-23.8%
* Plt: 38-86 x 10^9/L
* Cr: 0.5-0.9 mg/dL
* TCO2: 37-36 mmHg
* Glucose: 133-166 mg/dL
* Amylase: 32 IU/L
* Lipase: 467 IU/L
* LDH: 467 IU/L
* Ca++: 9.2 mg/dL
* Mg++: 2.2 mg/dL
* PO4: 4.3 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies are as follows:

* CXR: The patient has bilateral pleural effusions and a cardiomediastinal silhouette.
* CT head: The patient has a subdural hematoma and a transverse process fracture.
* CT torso: The patient has a liver mass and ascites.

The patient's medical complications include:

* Hypoxemia: The patient has respiratory failure, and is receiving oxygen therapy.
* Fever: The patient has a temperature of 38.3°C, and is receiving antibiotics for possible pneumonia.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level is elevated, and he is receiving diuretics to manage his fluid status.
* Altered mental status: The patient has altered mental status, likely secondary to hypoxia and liver encephalopathy.
* Anemia: The patient has anemia, and is receiving blood transfusions as needed.
* Coagulopathy: The patient has a coagulopathy, and is receiving blood products and coagulation factors.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Tracheostomy placement
* PEG placement
* Antibiotics for possible pneumonia
* Diuretics to manage fluid status
* Blood transfusions as needed
* Coagulation factor replacement
* Lactulose and rifaximin for treatment of encephalopathy
* Vasopressors as needed
* Mechanical ventilation
* Oxygen therapy

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient has respiratory failure, and is at risk for further deterioration.
* Cardiac failure: The patient has cardiac dysfunction, and is at risk for further deterioration.
* Hepatic failure: The patient has ESLD, and is at risk for further deterioration.
* Renal failure: The patient has renal dysfunction, and is at risk for further deterioration.
* Bleeding: The patient has a coagulopathy, and is at risk for further bleeding.
* Infection: The patient has a fever, and is at risk for further infection.

The patient's disposition is to begin screening for rehabilitation, and to consider placement in a long-term acute care facility.

Summary:

The patient is a 46-year-old male with end-stage liver disease (ESLD) who has been admitted to the ICU due to respiratory failure, sepsis, and altered mental status. He has a history of intraparenchymal hemorrhage, hepatic encephalopathy, and decompensated liver disease. The patient has been intubated multiple times and has received various treatments, including antibiotics, diuretics, and anticoagulants.

Current Status:

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and on minimal support, with a tracheostomy tube in place. He has a respiratory acidosis with metabolic alkalosis.
* Cardiovascular: The patient's blood pressure is stable, with a heart rate of 87 beats per minute.
* Neurological: The patient has altered mental status, likely secondary to hypoxia and hepatic encephalopathy.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has ascites, varices, and encephalopathy.
* Coagulation: The patient has a mild coagulopathy, with a platelet count of 73 K/uL.

Potential Medical Complications:

Based on the patient's current status and medical history, the following potential medical complications may arise:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory acidosis with metabolic alkalosis may worsen, leading to further respiratory failure.
* Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may progress, leading to multi-organ dysfunction.
* Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's hepatic encephalopathy may worsen, leading to further neurological deterioration.
* Coagulopathy: The patient's mild coagulopathy may worsen, leading to bleeding complications.
* Infection: The patient may develop a secondary infection, such as pneumonia or urinary tract infection.

Plan:

The patient will continue to receive supportive care, including mechanical ventilation, antibiotics, and anticoagulants. The patient's tracheostomy tube will be weaned to a tracheostomy collar, and he will be evaluated for possible tracheostomy decannulation. The patient's coagulopathy will be monitored, and he will receive further treatment as necessary. The patient's family will be educated on his condition and treatment plan.

 SUBDURAL HEMORRHAGE (SDH)

   complicated by intraparenchymal bleed, pneumonia, encephalopathy and
   current hypoxemia.
   .

   cloacae which is pan-sensitive.  Continues to spike, however, despite
   broad coverage with antibiotics.  ABG demonstrates respiratory acidosis
   with metabolic alkalosis.  Acute incident today was in the context of

   stable over several days.  Minimal bleeding with suctioning.  On [**11-23**]
   patient had 2 units PRBC transfused without appropriate increase in

Summary:

The patient is a 46-year-old male with end-stage liver disease (ESLD) and a history of ascites, varices, and encephalopathy. He was admitted with respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, and hypernatremia. He has been treated with antibiotics for pneumonia and has had multiple episodes of intubation and extubation. He has also had a subdural hemorrhage (SDH) and a transverse process fracture.

The patient's current status is:

* Respiratory failure: The patient has been intubated and is on minimal support. He has been weaned to a trach collar and is being treated with antibiotics for pneumonia.
* Fever: The patient has a fever of unknown origin (FUO) and is being treated with antibiotics for possible pneumonia and sepsis.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels have returned to normal.
* Coagulopathy: The patient has a mild coagulopathy and is being monitored for bleeding.
* Head bleed: The patient had a head bleed after a fall and has been treated with anticonvulsants.
* Altered mental status: The patient has an altered mental status due to hypoxia and is being treated with lactulose and rifaximin.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia is stable.
* ESLD: The patient has ESLD due to EtOH use and has a MELD score of 28.

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if his pneumonia does not respond to treatment.
* Sepsis: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count suggest that he may be at risk for sepsis.
* Bleeding: The patient's coagulopathy and history of bleeding may put him at risk for further bleeding.
* Infection: The patient's ESLD and history of ascites and varices may increase his risk for infection.
* Seizures: The patient's history of head bleed and altered mental status may put him at risk for seizures.
* Liver failure: The patient's ESLD may worsen if he does not receive proper treatment and care.

Recommendations:

* Continue treatment for pneumonia and sepsis.
* Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust his treatment as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's coagulopathy and bleeding risk.
* Continue to treat the patient's ESLD with lactulose and rifaximin.
* Consider placing a PEG tube to provide nutrition and hydration.
* Consider referring the patient to a liver transplant center for further evaluation and treatment.
* Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and adjust his treatment as needed.

Summary:

The patient is a 46-year-old male with end-stage liver disease (ESLD), complicated by intraparenchymal bleed, pneumonia, encephalopathy, and hypoxemia. He has been intubated four times during this hospitalization, without significant improvement in his mental status. The patient has a history of ethanol use and has been diagnosed with cirrhosis of the liver, alcoholic.

The patient's current condition includes:

* Hypernatremia (high sodium levels) has resolved
* Altered mental status, likely secondary to hypoxia, is improving
* Coagulopathy, likely related to liver disease, is stable
* Anemia is stable
* ESLD is stable, with a MELD score of 28
* Transverse process fractures are non-operative
* Shallow toe ulcer is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics
* Febrile neutropenia is being treated with antibiotics
* Patient has a tracheostomy and is on ventilator support

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he may require ongoing ventilator support.
* Sepsis: The patient has a history of pneumonia and is febrile, which increases the risk of sepsis.
* Bleeding: The patient has a coagulopathy and has had bleeding episodes in the past, which may increase the risk of bleeding complications.
* Encephalopathy: The patient has a history of encephalopathy and may be at risk for further neurological deterioration.
* Liver failure: The patient's ESLD is advanced, and he may be at risk for further liver failure.
* Infection: The patient has a history of pneumonia and may be at risk for further infections, such as sepsis or abscesses.

Plan:

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
* Continue antibiotics for pneumonia and sepsis.
* Monitor the patient's coagulopathy and transfuse blood products as needed.
* Continue lactulose and rifaximin to manage encephalopathy.
* Trend the patient's MELD score to monitor his liver function.
* Consider PEG placement to manage his nutritional needs.
* Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust his medication regimen as needed.
* Consider further imaging studies, such as a CT scan, to monitor for any signs of bleeding or infection.

The patient's current condition is complicated by:

1. Respiratory failure: He has pneumonia and is growing Enterobacter cloacae, which is pan-sensitive. He has been intubated four times without significant improvement in his mental status.
2. Fever: The etiology is unclear, but he is being treated for possible PNA and SBP.
3. Coagulopathy: He has mild DIC on admission, and his platelet count is low. He has been transfused with platelets and has had minimal bleeding.
4. Head bleed: He had a fall on [**11-11**] and had a head bleed, which is stable.
5. Altered mental status: He has likely secondary to hypoxia, improving.
6. Anemia: His hemoglobin level is stable.
7. ESLD: He has decompensated liver disease with a previous history of encephalopathy.
8. Transverse process fractures: He has non-operative fractures.
9. Shallow toe ulcer: He has mild cellulitis treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.
10. FEN: He is on tubefeds and needs PEG placement.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38.3°C (101°F)

The patient's plan includes:

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure

* Renal failure
* Cardiovascular complications

The patient's discharge plan includes:

* Begin screening for rehab

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 46-year-old male with end-stage liver disease (ESLD) complicated by ascites, varices, and encephalopathy. He has had a course of pneumonia, intraparenchymal bleed, and encephalopathy, leading to respiratory failure and need for tracheostomy and PEG placement.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: Hypoxemic with ABG demonstrating respiratory acidosis and metabolic alkalosis.
* Cardiovascular status: Hypotensive with a blood pressure of 99/46 mmHg.
* Neurological status: Altered mental status likely secondary to hypoxia and hepatic encephalopathy.
* Hematological status: Coagulopathy with a platelet count of 52 and International Normalized Ratio (INR) of 2.4.
* Gastrointestinal status: Ascites, varices, and encephalopathy.
* Renal status: Normal creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels.
* Hepatic status: ESLD with a Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) score of 28.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory acidosis and metabolic alkalosis may worsen, leading to further respiratory compromise.
2. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy may worsen, leading to bleeding or bruising.
3. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's encephalopathy may worsen, leading to further neurological compromise.
4. Infections: The patient's immunocompromised state may increase his risk of developing infections, such as pneumonia or sepsis.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's ascites and varices may lead to gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Renal failure: The patient's ESLD may lead to renal failure.
7. Sepsis: The patient's immunocompromised state and presence of indwelling lines may increase his risk of developing sepsis.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continue tracheostomy and PEG placement.
* Continue antibiotics for pneumonia.
* Continue anticoagulation therapy for coagulopathy.
* Continue lactulose and rifaximin for hepatic encephalopathy.
* Monitor for signs of bleeding or bruising.
* Monitor for signs of respiratory failure.
* Monitor for signs of infection.
* Monitor for signs of gastrointestinal bleeding.
* Monitor for signs of renal failure.
* Monitor for signs of sepsis.
* Continue to follow up with hepatology and neurosurgery services.

Based on the progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 46-year-old male with end-stage liver disease (ESLD) and ascites, varices, and encephalopathy. He has a history of intraparenchymal bleed, pneumonia, and encephalopathy, which has led to respiratory failure, fever, and hypernatremia. He is currently intubated and on tracheostomy collar.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Elevated liver enzymes (ALT, AST, and alkaline phosphatase)
* Coagulopathy with a prolonged PT and PTT
* Anemia with a low HCT
* Hypernatremia
* Elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine
* Elevated liver function tests (LFTs)

The patient's medical conditions include:

* ESLD with ascites, varices, and encephalopathy
* Intraparenchymal bleed
* Pneumonia
* Encephalopathy
* Respiratory failure
* Fever
* Hypernatremia
* Coagulopathy
* Anemia

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Failure to heal or infection at the tracheostomy site
* Leakage or bleeding from the tracheostomy site
* Infection or sepsis
* Respiratory failure or worsening of respiratory status
* Cardiac complications due to hypoxia or hypercapnia
* Neurological complications due to encephalopathy or hypoxia
* Gastrointestinal complications due to ascites, varices, or encephalopathy
* Hemorrhagic complications due to coagulopathy or liver disease

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Tracheostomy and PEG placement
* Antibiotic therapy for pneumonia and fever
* Diuretic therapy for ascites and edema
* Coagulation factor replacement and blood product transfusions as needed
* Lactulose and rifaximin for hepatic encephalopathy
* Proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy for stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Venodynes for ascites and edema
* Full code status
* Disposition to LTAC for rehabilitation

   - Discontinue free water flushes
   .
